description:
Tolypeutes matacus, commonly known as the three-banded armadillo, is a small species of armadillo native to South America. It belongs to the family Chlamyphoridae and the genus Tolypeutes.

The three-banded armadillo is characterized by its distinctive shell, which is composed of three movable bands that allow the animal to curl up into a ball for protection. This species has a rounded body shape, short legs, and a small, pointed head. The shell is typically yellowish-brown in color with darker bands.

These armadillos are primarily found in dry, open habitats such as savannas, grasslands, and scrublands in parts of Argentina, Bolivia, Paraguay, and southern Brazil. They are largely nocturnal and solitary, spending the day sleeping in burrows or under vegetation.

Tolypeutes matacus is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of insects, small vertebrates, and plant materials. They play an important role in their ecosystem by contributing to the decomposition of organic matter and dispersing seeds.

Conservation-wise, the three-banded armadillo is classified as Least Concern by the IUCN, although its populations may be threatened by habitat loss and hunting in some regions.
